ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ENTRY OF JAPANESE GIRLS INTO
COLONY TO BECOME SECONDARY WIVES


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he is aware that Japanese girls are being

permitted to enter the Colony to be secondary wives of local residents; and why this is being allowed.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware of any such case. The second part of the question asked by the Member for Queenstown therefore does not arise.

INCONVENIENCE AND HARDSHIP CAUSED TO
SOCIAL WELFARE ALLOWANCE RECIPIENTS AND
POSSIBLE PAYMENT THROUGH POST OFFICES


    2. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he is aware of the inconvenience to people in having to wait in a long queue, and of the hardship to them in having to incur transport expenses, when collecting allowances under the Public Assistance Scheme at the Social Welfare Department; and whether he will arrange for such allowances to be paid at the post offices nearest to their homes.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the inconvenience referred to by the Member for Tiong Bahru. For this reason additional staff have been recruited and are now being trained for the setting up of branch relief centres for the convenience of relief recipients. It is hoped to set up two such branches early next year, one in Bukit Panjang and the other in Geylang.

    Sir, the use of post offices for this purpose has already been suggested as part of a general review of the social security system in Singapore. I would like to assure the Member for Tiong Bahru that if the arrangements for using post offices are practicable, they will be implemented.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Cannot the travelling vans be used for that purpose?

SINGAPORE SPORTS STADIUM


    3. Mr Soh Ghee Soon asked the Chief Secretary, with reference to the Singapore Sports Stadium,-

    (a) how many members are at present serving on the Board of Management;

    (b) how many vacancies are there in the Board;

    (c) whether any action has been taken to fill the vacancies;

    (d) whether the Government will provide the Board of Management with the necessary funds and facilities to build a sports stadium;

    (e) whether any land has been earmarked for the building of such a stadium; and

    (f) whether he is aware of the inactivity of the Board of Management and the reasons therefor.

    Mr W. A. C. Goode: Sir, the Stadium Board has been allowed to lapse because the funds required to build the stadium were not forthcoming. In the circumstances, I do not think that the detailed points raised by the Member call for a reply.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us then is there any intention by the Government to re-establish this Board in view of the sports activities in Singapore?

    Mr Goode: The position of the Board, Sir, is that it has been allowed to lapse because we can see no prospect of the funds required to build a stadium being obtainable. In the absence of some prospect of funds I do not think any useful purpose will be served by reappointing the Board.

COMMITTEE TO REVIEW INCOME
TAX ORDINANCE


    4. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Financial Secretary whether and what action has been taken to set up a Committee to review the Income Tax Ordinance (Cap. 166).

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, the hon. Member will recall that during the debate on his motion at the May sitting of the Assembly, the Hon. the Chief Minister said that taxation policy was the sole

Column: 2522

responsibility of Government and that he was not prepared to delegate this responsibility to any independent body. Again the hon. Member will recall that during the same debate the Acting Financial Secretary said that a suitable committee already existed in the Economic Committee of the Council of Ministers and indicated that this Committee would be charged with the task of examining the suggestion made by the hon. Member. Sir, the answer to the hon. Member's question is therefore that a committee is already in existence and that it will consider suggestions as soon as the necessary background material has been collected.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. the Financial Secretary tell us when will the report of this Committee be made public or when the public will know who are the members of this Committee?

    Mr Hart: Sir, I can tell the hon. Member the composition of the Committee. It consists of the Hon. the Chief Minister, the Hon. the Minister for Communications and Works, the Hon. the Minister for Commerce and Industry, and myself, and at all meetings of the Committee the advice of the Economic Adviser is obtained and in this particular instance the advice of the Comptroller of Income Tax will also be obtained.

    I do not know when the Committee will be in a position to report to the Council of Ministers (that being the body to which it must report). We are at the moment in the process of obtaining as much information from neighbouring and other countries about schemes for dependants' allowances which are in existence there and about their experience in operating these schemes. This information is voluminous and will take some time to digest and consider. In these circumstances, I regret that I cannot give any indication when the Committee will be able to report to the Council of Ministers.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. the Financial Secretary tell us has there been any meeting held so far?

    Mr Hart: The Economic Committee of the Council of Ministers of course meets constantly, Sir, It has not yet met on this particular question of dependants' allowances for the simple reason that the basic information which I have detailed has not yet been obtained in full.

FUTURE EMPLOYMENT OF S.I.T. STAFF AND
ANXIETY ABOUT TAKE-OVER BY
NEW HOUSING AUTHORITY


    5. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether, in view of the anxiety of the officers of the Singapore Improvement Trust regarding their future terms of employment or retirement, he will state-

    (a) when the proposed new Housing Authority will be established;

    (b) whether it is intended that the Authority will take over the staff of the Singapore Improvement Trust; and

    (c) how such staff will be affected in respect of their terms of employment or retirement by the taking-over.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, the reply to (a) is that the new Housing Authority will be set up as soon as legislation has been prepared and the administrative arrangements can be made for this purpose; (b), it is intended that the Authority will take over the staff of the Singapore Improvement Trust connected with its housing functions; and (c), consultations will be held with the associations of Trust officers in respect of the terms of employment with the new Authority. Government's views and proposals have been conveyed to the Trust, who have informed their officers of them.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker. Sir, can the Hon. Minister tell us how long or how many months approximately is meant by the term 'as soon as' possible?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Sir, it will probably be within a matter of months.

HOLD-UP OF LAND DEVELOPMENT, AND GOVERNMENT'S POLICY
ON MASTER PLAN AND OPPORTUNITY TO DEBATE IT


    6. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing-

    (a) whether he is aware that land development is being held up and what are the reasons therefor;

    (b) whether he will state how soon the Government's policy in respect of the Master Plan will be made public; and

    (c) whether this House will be given an opportunity to debate this policy.

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, (a) I am not aware of any general holding up of private development of land. If the hon. Member has any specific case in mind I am prepared to look into the matter and see whether any delay can be avoided; (b) alterations to the Master Plan are being made as a result of objections and representations made by some owners when the Plan was published and thrown open for public exhibition. These objections and representations were considered by an Inspector specially appointed for the purpose, who has submitted his report to Government. This has been considered by Government and directions have been given for alterations to the Plan to be made. When these alterations have been completed the Master Plan will be made public after formal approval by the Governor in Council. (c) If the hon. Member so wishes, he may, in the ordinary course, Sir, file a motion for a debate.

UNSIGHTLY CONDITION OF CROWN LAND ALONG DUNEARN ROAD


    7. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Local Government, Lends and Housing whether he is aware of the unsightly conditions of the Crown Land between Dunearn Road and Bukit Timah Road from Newton Circus to the Farrer Road junction; and whether the

    (a) how many persons have applied to rent them;

SEIZURE OF BOAT BY INDONESIAN POLICE


    10. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he is aware that, after the seizure of the fishing boat Hock Huat on 30th July last, two Singapore fishermen in distress were arrested by an Indonesian police patrol boat last month and imprisoned for two weeks; whether he has inquired or will inquire into the incident; and whether he will make a statement on the matter.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, the hon. Member appears to have been misinformed. Careful enquiry has shown that the circumstances were in fact as follows. A pleasure boat with two Singapore passengers, one of whom is a fisherman, was detained by the Indonesian authorities when they were off Pulau Kusu on 25th July, 1957, that is five days before the Hock Huat incident. This pleasure craft developed engine trouble after a storm off Pulau Kusu and was taken to Pulau Samboe where the two passengers were detained in the police station for 15 days. They were subsequently released, the Chief Police Officer of Pulau Samboe confirming that they had not committed any offence. The persons concerned who were detained had no permit to enter Indonesian territorial waters.

PROGRESS OF LIM CHU KANG EXPERIMENTAL
VETERINARY AND HUSBANDRY STATION


    11. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the progress of the Lim Chu Kang Experimental Veterinary and Husbandry Station.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Yes, Sir. The Lim Chu Kang District Veterinary Station was planned in 1954 and commenced operations the following year. The extension work done from this station is highly successful and during the last 18 months over 500 stud animals and 1,000 poultry have been bred and distributed to farmers and co-operative societies. There is a long waiting list for such assistance. The pedigree stock at Lim Chu Kang include pigs and poultry presented by the Commonwealth and Australia under the Colombo Plan. Nearly 1,500,000 pigs and poultry have been given protective vaccinations by the team operating from Lim Chu Kang so far this year.

    Lim Chu Kang is used to produce improved stock but the normal research work planned for Sembawang has been increased as far as facilities allow since Dr Kelly arrived in Singapore in December. The research work is conducted amongst pigs, poultry and cattle and the work now in progress involves establishing parental strains from which controlled breeding work will evolve. Eighteen strains of pigs have been selected and the progeny which will perform the parental strain are now coming forward and from these the first generation of developed stock will be produced. One thousand two hundred poultry are now growing under trap-nest conditions and the first parental strains will be selected from these birds. Their progeny will not be ready until March because there is no room at Lim Chu Kang to develop this work further. Special poultry extension work is planned for the central station at Sembawang.

Column: 2528



    There are 40 cows and four bulls from Pakistan at Lim Chu Kang and the first progeny are now being produced. They will be distributed when they reach suitable age.

    As facilities for nutritional research do not exist at Lim Chu Kang this work is planned for the central research station which it is hoped to operate at Sembawang.

    Although increased inoculation services and also the issue of improved stock from Lim Chu Kang have increased the production of pigs and poultry all over Singapore in recent years, a brief survey made in January this year showed that in the Lim Chu Kang area production was 300 per cent higher than in other parts of the island. This is the more remarkable because four years ago the Lim Chu Kang area was the most poorly developed area in Singapore for livestock. Now, more pigs and poultry are produced there than in any other area of comparable size in Malaya.

    One of the most important functions at Lim Chu Kang lies in the benefits from the close associations between the station staff and surrounding farmers, which have induced a degree of trust and faith in Government policy of helping farmers with their everyday difficulties. The operations of the station show very clearly that farmers' troubles require on-the-spot help from officers who know their problems and are equipped to render prompt assistance.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in spite of the excellent work done by the station may I ask the Hon. Minister whether he is aware that it still cannot cope with the work of meeting the needs of the farmers there?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: I am aware, Sir, that there is need for further expansion of veterinary department services to the farmers all over the island, and with that purpose we are now going ahead with building the Sembawang station.

NUMBER OF FARMERS' AND FISHERMEN'S CO-OPERATIVES
FORMED WITH GOVERNMENT HELP


    12. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry how many of the following classes of co-operative societies have been formed, up to date, with the help of the Government-

    (a) Farmers' Co-operative Societies; and

    (b) Fishermen's Co-operative Societies.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The answer to question (a), Sir, is 11 including an agricultural co-operative union. The answer to question (b) is four.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: May I ask the Hon. the Minister whether any loans have been given to the societies?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Off-hand, Sir, I can recollect one case where we gave a loan of $4,000 to a Ponggol fishermen's co-operative society. That was some months back. There was another case where certain fishermen suffered damage to their fishing boats and a loan was approved but it seems they were reluctant to accept the loan.

DAILY RADIO BROADCASTS OF
WHOLESALE PRICES OF FOODSTUFFS


    13. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will consider causing a daily broadcast in Chinese and Malay by Radio Malaya of the wholesale prices of livestock, poultry, eggs, fish, vegetables, bananas and coconut.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The answer, Sir, is no. To both consumer and producer alike, such daily broadcasts are not particularly useful and are not popular because (a) only the previous day's prices can be given at a time when housewives are out marketing and when they already know the previous day's prices, and (b) by the time the prices are available for broadcasting the producers have already sold their produce.

Column: 2530

Such broadcasts therefore do not give the housewives an idea of prices before they go to market and do not help the producers to get better prices for their products.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: I am afraid the Hon. the Minister misunderstands the question. What I want are broadcasts of the prices of livestock delivered by the farmers.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, would the Member please repeat his question?

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: My object is to have broadcasts of the prices as paid by the middlemen to the farmers.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The prices, Sir, paid by the middlemen to the farmers vary with different middlemen in different areas. They depend on the cleverness of the middlemen and probably also on the cleverness of the farmers in trying to get the best prices for their produce. CRIMINAL PROCEDURE CODE
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.22 a.m.

    The Attorney-General (Mr E. P. Shanks): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." The second clause of this Bill is designed to ensure that the power to pass a sentence of preventive detention, which must by law be for a period of at least five years, shall be exercised

Column: 2531

only by the High Court. As the Criminal Procedure Code stands at present, it is not clear that these sentences of preventive detention can only be imposed by the High Court, although it is clear that the somewhat lesser sentence of corrective training is one restricted to the High Court. Clause 2 will make the position quite clear.

    Clause 3 of this Bill is designed to avoid any doubt as to the powers of courts to remand accused persons in such custody as the courts think fit. It is necessary sometimes for accused persons to be given the opportunity, in their own interests, of pointing out individuals or places which have a bearing on cases under investigation. This cannot be done if the person is remanded in prison, and it is often undesirable, particularly in the initial stages of investigation, that a person should be granted bail merely for the purpose of enabling him to point out witnesses or places that are relevant to the case. This clause will bring the Criminal Procedure Code of the colony into line with the provisions which have been in existence in the Federation for some years and have worked well there, but with the difference that whereas in the Federation there is a period of 15 days during which this custody other than prison can subsist, it is thought that in Singapore the ordinary period of eight days should suffice.

    Clause 4 of the Bill is in two parts. The first part is designed to make the offences of unlawful assembly and rioting not bailable as of right. It is considered that in cases of this nature, the courts should have a discretion to refuse bail if the circumstances so require, and in order that they should be able to do that, it is thought right to make the alterations referred to in paragraph (a) of clause 4.

    The second part of this clause is designed to remove any doubt that might exist regarding a police officer's power to arrest without warrant a person who obstructs him in the discharge of his duties. Whereas section 31 of the Code

Column: 2532

quite clearly gives police officers that power, Schedule A to the Code - in referring to section 186 of the Penal Code - at present says that ordinarily a warrant should be obtained before arrest. Quite clearly with offences of this nature, immediate arrest is necessary. This amendment will remove the doubts that have existed in the past.

    The fifth clause deals with the provisions of what is elsewhere known as the Borstal system. At present Schedule D to the Criminal Procedure Code which lays down the detailed provisions regarding reformative training, as we call it in Singapore, allow of a person being kept in a reformative training centre for a period of more than four years, whereas the normal practice is that a person should be so kept for only three years as a maximum and for the remainder of the four years from the date of the imposition of the sentence be under supervision. That period of release under supervision is regarded as one of the very important parts of reformative training and it is thought that the system would suffer if we allowed to remain in the law this power to keep a person in detention beyond the ordinary period of three years.

    It might be thought that an anomaly had crept in when the Schedule was originally drafted and this clause is designed to put the matter right and to ensure that every person who is sentenced to reformative training shall have the opportunity of a period of freedom under supervision after he has undergone the training in the reformative training centre itself.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. [Mr Shanks].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read the Third time and passed.

RAFFLES MUSEUM BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.32 a.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to signify to the House that I have His Excellency the Governor's consent to move this Bill.

    The Assistant Minister for Education (Inche Mohamed Sidik Bin Haji Abdul Hamid): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, in moving this Bill, which provides for the management and control of the Raffles Museum, I wish to state that for many years the Raffles Museum and the Raffles Library have been working under an out-of-date Raffles Society Ordinance. The former union of the Museum and Library was to a large extent fortuitous and not in the best interests of either once they had begun to develop. The separation in the administration of the Raffles Museum and Raffles Library took place at the beginning of the year 1955 which in effect rendered obsolete the Raffles Society Ordinance.

    This Bill is a simple one because the statutory requirements of a display and research museum are very limited, and this Bill now brought up for its Second Reading contains only two significant points to which I would like to draw the attention of the Assembly. One of the innovations is in clauses 3 (3) and 6 whereby the Governor may by notification in the Gazette authorise any member of the staff to exercise within the Museum and Museum grounds the powers of a police officer. This is an important point since previously although the Director was responsible for the safety of the building and collections he had no general authority for preventing misdemeanour. I am sure that hon. Members will agree that the valuable collections in the Museum need protection and that the Director should be empowered to deal with any contingency that may arise.

    The second innovation, Sir, in this Bill is in clause 4, which gives official

Column: 2534

recognition to the Advisory Committee on Art, which was set up in 1953 and 1954, in anticipation of the Raffles Library moving to its own building. This provision under clause 4 will give this Advisory Committee a permanent status so that in the years to come we can hope that Raffles Museum will contain a collection of objects illustrating the art of the Chinese people, the Malays and the Indians who have by their culture and way of life made Singapore into what it is today. It is also hoped that this Art Committee will in the course of time assist the Director in building up exhibition galleries in the Museum devoted to art.

    I beg to move, Sir.

    Question proposed.

10.36 a.m.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to speak on one aspect of this Bill which I consider to be rather unsatisfactory and which falls short of what I think we should aim at in legislation of this sort. I refer to clause 4 (1) and (3) (a) which reads as follows:

    "(1) There shall be constituted an Arts Committee appointed by the Minister comprising of persons who are knowledgeable in, or have specific information on, matters pertaining to Chinese, Indian and Malay art.

    (3) (a) The functions of the Arts Committee shall be to advise the Director on the acquisition of a collection of objects illustrating particularly the arts of China, Malays and India, in order to reflect the art, culture and way of life of the various communities who have settled in Malaya;".

    Sir, my objection is to the implied limitation of the arts to Chinese, Indian and Malay art. My first reaction, I must confess, was to suggest an amendment for the inclusion of European art with the other three, thinking on the lines of our present multilingualism, but my second thought was that this amendment would not be getting us away from the narrow, somewhat communal drafting of this clause, which is entirely alien to a proper artistic outlook. We have in sub-clause (1) of clause 4 the inclusion, for example, of Malay art but what about Malayan art, for it is that very fusion of the arts which we would like to see encouraged in this country: and yet Malayan art finds no place in this clause.

Column: 2535



    After all it is a fact that there is already developing a Singapore school - or if "school" is too ambitious a word, a Singapore "style" - of painting which is individual to this island. Cheong Soopieng is a Singapore artist - or a Malay - an artist if you prefer it - of whom we have every reason to be proud, and there are other painters here of considerable promise. The work of a young man called Chiao Hsien was exhibited the other day which is distinctly interesting.

    If we limit ourselves to Chinese, Indian and Malay art in this piece of legislation, we are also, by implication, leaving out Indonesian art, which has had a considerable influence in this country, or Siamese art, or the art of the Philippines of which we have had a recent exposition in Singapore. And when Singapore could so easily be, through its universities and flourishing societies, a centre and a fountain and a blending of the art forms, it would be a thousand pities not to reflect this even in a minor piece of legislation like this Raffles Museum Bill.

    I would therefore like to see clause 4 (1) and (3) (a) amended to read as follows:
